raw_results.scenario_label: Delay_Driver_Profiler case evaluating 18h delay for a 5yo male with supracondylar fracture.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: brought to the emergency department on Friday at 17:00...

engine_output.raw_input: A 5-year-old male was brought to the emergency department on Friday at 17:00 after a fall from monkey bars, resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon examination, the patient exhibited a pucker sign, indicating potential nerve injury. The neurovascular assessment revealed a white, cold pulseless hand. The surgery was scheduled for Saturday at 11:00, resulting in an 18-hour delay. The surgical team indicated that the delay was due to OR availability and the need for further imaging. There were no signs of compartment syndrome documented, although the patient's extremity was closely monitored throughout his stay.
signals: The surgery was scheduled for Saturday at 11:00, resulting in an 18-hour delay.
The surgical team indicated that the delay was due to OR availability.
The surgical team indicated that the delay was due to... the need for further imaging.
resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture.
The neurovascular assessment revealed a white, cold pulseless hand.
the patient exhibited a pucker sign, indicating potential nerve injury.
There were no signs of compartment syndrome documented, although the patient's extremity was closely monitored throughout his stay.

raw_results.scenario_label: Safety_Signal case for a 4yo male with supracondylar fracture and normal neurovascular status.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: brought to the emergency department on Saturday at 12:00, surgery was scheduled for 14:00...

engine_output.raw_input: A 4-year-old male was brought to the emergency department on Saturday at 12:00 following a trampoline accident that resulted in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Clinical examination showed a stable neurovascular status, with a warm, pink hand and good capillary refill. The injury was classified as Gartland type II, and he was scheduled for surgery at 14:00, resulting in a 2-hour delay. The surgical team noted that there were no signs of compartment syndrome or neurovascular compromise during the assessment. The patient's parents were informed of the condition and the planned intervention without any immediate concerns raised.
signals: scheduled for surgery at 14:00, resulting in a 2-hour delay
The injury was classified as Gartland type II

The surgical team noted that there were no signs of compartment syndrome or neurovascular compromise during the assessment

raw_results.scenario_label: Documentation_Gap case for a 6yo female with supracondylar fracture and AIN palsy.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency room at 21:00, AIN palsy, evidenced by the inability to perform the 'OK' sign...

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old female presented to the emergency room at 21:00 on Saturday after falling off a trampoline, resulting in a right supracondylar humerus fracture. Initial assessment indicated an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy, evidenced by the inability to perform the 'OK' sign. Despite the urgent need for surgical intervention, the surgery was delayed until 03:00 on Sunday, which amounted to a 6-hour wait. There were inconsistencies noted in the documentation regarding the neurovascular assessment performed at the time of arrival, as the notes failed to explicitly state the presence of the AIN palsy initially. The surgical team was alerted, and the patient was taken to OR with a complicated but manageable postoperative course.
signals: Despite the urgent need for surgical intervention, the surgery was delayed until 03:00 on Sunday, which amounted to a 6-hour wait.

There were inconsistencies noted in the documentation regarding the neurovascular assessment performed at the time of arrival, as the notes failed to explicitly state the presence of the AIN palsy initially.
Initial assessment indicated an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy, evidenced by the inability to perform the 'OK' sign.
resulting in a right supracondylar humerus fracture.

raw_results.scenario_label: Delay_Driver_Profiler case for a 7yo male with supracondylar fracture and pucker sign.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: brought to the emergency department at 23:00, pucker sign indicating potential significant soft tissue injury...

engine_output.raw_input: A 7-year-old male was brought to the emergency department at 23:00 on Friday after suffering a left supracondylar humerus fracture during a football game. Upon examination, a pucker sign was noted, indicating potential significant soft tissue injury. The patient was not taken to the operating room until 09:00 on Saturday, leading to a 10-hour delay in surgical intervention. The delay was primarily attributed to the unavailability of surgical staff during the night and a lack of OR capacity. The child's condition was stable, but the extended wait raised concerns regarding the potential for complications. Postoperatively, he was monitored closely for any signs of neurovascular compromise.

raw_results.scenario_label: Exclusion_Hunter case testing neurovascular status in a pediatric SCH fracture with a 2h delay.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: arrived Sunday 18:00, surgery Sunday 20:00...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old female presented with a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture following a scooter accident. Upon arrival at the emergency department at 18:00 on Sunday, she demonstrated normal neurovascular status with palpable radial and ulnar pulses, and no signs of compromise. The surgical team was notified promptly, and surgery was scheduled for 20:00 the same evening, resulting in a 2-hour delay from arrival to surgery. The fracture was stable, and there were no complicating factors such as additional trauma or neurovascular deficits. The patient was discharged without any immediate complications.
signals: surgery was scheduled for 20:00 the same evening, resulting in a 2-hour delay from arrival to surgery.

engine_output.raw_input: A 4-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after sustaining a supracondylar humerus fracture from a slide accident. He arrived at 15:00 on Friday, exhibiting a pink pulseless hand, which raised immediate concerns for vascular compromise. The surgical intervention was delayed until 00:00 Saturday, resulting in a 9-hour wait. During the assessment, he was found to have no active bleeding, but the risk for potential compartment syndrome was noted. Given the significant delay and clinical findings, the case was classified as a clear fail for timely intervention.

She arrived at 17:00 on Thursday and was noted to have an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy, complicating her clinical picture. Surgery was eventually performed at 07:00 on Friday, which resulted in a 14-hour delay. Discrepancies were noted in the documentation regarding the timing of her AIN exam and the urgency of her surgical intervention, leading to a borderline classification.

raw_results.scenario_label: Process_Auditor case investigating compartment syndrome and delays in surgery for a pediatric SCH fracture.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: arrived Saturday 20:00, surgery Sunday 01:00...

engine_output.raw_input: A 5-year-old male was brought in after a playdate accident resulting in a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture. He arrived at the emergency department at 20:00 on Saturday, exhibiting early signs of compartment syndrome, including pain on passive stretch and increased muscle tension in the forearm. His surgery was not initiated until 01:00 on Sunday, resulting in a significant 5-hour delay. The clinical team documented the condition thoroughly but faced challenges in OR availability, which impacted timely intervention, marking this case as a clear fail.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: arrived Sunday 12:30, surgery Sunday 14:00, pucker sign observed...

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old female presented following a fall from a chair, leading to a supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival at 12:30 on Sunday, a notable pucker sign was observed, indicating possible brachialis involvement. The surgical team scheduled her for surgery at 14:00, resulting in a minimal delay of 1.5 hours. Her neurovascular exam was normal with no signs of compartment syndrome and all pulses intact. This case was classified as a clear pass due to the timely intervention and appropriate clinical management.
signals: The surgical team scheduled her for surgery at 14:00, resulting in a minimal delay of 1.5 hours.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department at 08:00, surgery at 08:30...

engine_output.raw_input: A 7-year-old male presented to the emergency department after falling from a tree while climbing. Upon examination at 08:00 on Saturday, he exhibited a Gartland type II supracondylar humerus fracture. Notably, the patient had a pink pulseless hand, and his neurovascular assessment showed intact sensation, although a radial nerve check was pending. The surgical team was alerted, and the patient was taken to the operating room at 08:30, resulting in a 0.5-hour delay from the recommended time to OR. There were no signs of compartment syndrome noted during the pre-operative evaluation, which was documented clearly in the medical record.

raw_results.scenario_label: Safety_Signal case exploring red flags in supracondylar fracture management.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: arrived at 22:00, surgery at 04:00, AIN motor exam showing inability to form 'OK' sign...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old male presented to the emergency department after suffering a supracondylar humerus fracture during a group sport activity. He arrived at 22:00 on Saturday, and upon examination, he exhibited significant weakness in his right hand with an AIN motor exam showing an inability to form the 'OK' sign. Surgery was not initiated until 04:00 the next day, resulting in a 6-hour delay. The evaluation noted potential signs of early compartment syndrome, but these were not acted upon in a timely manner, raising concerns about the management of his condition.
signals: Surgery was not initiated until 04:00 the next day, resulting in a 6-hour delay.
The evaluation noted potential signs of early compartment syndrome, but these were not acted upon in a timely manner.

raw_results.scenario_label: Documentation_Gap case reviewing compartment syndrome notes.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: arrived at 10:00, surgery at 11:30...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old female arrived at the emergency department after a fall from playground equipment, resulting in a supracondylar humerus fracture. She was evaluated at 10:00 on Saturday. The clinical assessment revealed significant swelling and pain, with a documented diagnosis of compartment syndrome. Despite this, the surgery was delayed until 11:30, accounting for a 1.5-hour wait time. The documentation contained conflicting notes regarding the urgency of the situation and whether a fasciotomy was considered, leading to potential inconsistencies in the patient’s care plan.
signals: Despite this, the surgery was delayed until 11:30, accounting for a 1.5-hour wait time.

raw_results.scenario_label: Borderline 17.5h time-to-OR, pink pulseless hand, correctly managed overnight (Process_Auditor)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department at 10:00 PM...

engine_output.raw_input: A 7-year-old male presented to the emergency department at 10:00 PM following a fall from a tree, resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, a neurovascular assessment revealed a pink pulseless hand with intact capillary refill but diminished radial pulse. The orthopedic team was notified, and the decision was made to monitor overnight due to the stable condition. Surgery was scheduled for 03:30 AM the following day. Pre-operative assessments were conducted, including an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) motor exam which showed an 'OK sign' but no other deficits. The patient was taken to the operating room at 03:30 AM the next day, and the fracture was successfully reduced and pinned. No signs of compartment syndrome were noted during the post-op recovery.
signals: Surgery was scheduled for 03:30 AM the following day.
The patient presented at 10:00 PM and was taken to the operating room at 03:30 AM.
resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture.
a neurovascular assessment revealed a pink pulseless hand with intact capillary refill but diminished radial pulse.
No signs of compartment syndrome were noted during the post-op recovery.
diminished radial pulse.

raw_results.scenario_label: White, cold hand at arrival, delayed reduction with bad outcome (Safety_Signal + Preventability_Detective)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: white, cold hand at arrival, absent radial pulse...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old female was brought to the emergency department at 09:30 PM after falling off her bike, resulting in a right supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, the patient exhibited a white, cold hand, and the radial pulse was absent. Immediate neurovascular assessment indicated severe ischemia. The orthopedic team was notified, but due to OR schedule constraints, the reduction was delayed until 11:00 AM the next day. During the prolonged wait, the patient developed signs of compartment syndrome, requiring fasciotomy after the delayed reduction. Post-operative assessment revealed persistent motor deficits in the AIN distribution. This case raises concerns about the preventability of the deteriorating neurovascular status.
signals: the reduction was delayed until 11:00 AM the next day

raw_results.scenario_label: AIN palsy documented but summary says 'neurovascularly intact' (Documentation_Gap)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: discharge summary incorrectly stated that the patient was 'neurovascularly intact'...

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old boy was evaluated at 08:15 PM after sustaining a left elbow injury while playing. Imaging confirmed a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture. The initial exam documented an absent AIN motor function with an 'OK sign' failure, but the discharge summary incorrectly stated that the patient was 'neurovascularly intact.' The surgical intervention was performed at 01:00 AM following a thorough neurovascular assessment, which included radial and ulnar nerve checks. Post-operative notes confirmed the presence of AIN palsy. This discrepancy raises concerns regarding the accuracy of documentation in the patient's records.
signals: Surgical intervention was performed at 01:00 AM following a thorough neurovascular assessment.
Imaging confirmed a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture.

Post-operative notes confirmed the presence of AIN palsy.

raw_results.scenario_label: Brachialis pucker sign requiring unavoidable open reduction (Preventability_Detective)

engine_output.raw_input: A 9-year-old female presented at 07:45 PM after a fall from a swing, resulting in a left supracondylar humerus fracture. The orthopedic examination revealed a notable brachialis pucker sign, indicating significant soft tissue compromise. Neurovascular assessment showed a pink, warm hand with intact capillary refill, but the indication for closed reduction was poor due to the pucker sign. An open reduction was deemed necessary and performed at 10:30 PM. Post-operatively, the patient was closely monitored for complications, but the initial assessment raised questions about whether the need for an open reduction could have been prevented with more timely intervention.
signals: the initial assessment raised questions about whether the need for an open reduction could have been prevented with more timely intervention.
The orthopedic examination revealed a notable brachialis pucker sign, indicating significant soft tissue compromise. An open reduction was deemed necessary and performed at 10:30 PM.

The orthopedic examination revealed a notable brachialis pucker sign, indicating significant soft tissue compromise.
Neurovascular assessment showed a pink, warm hand with intact capillary refill.
Post-operatively, the patient was closely monitored for complications.

raw_results.scenario_label: Escalating pain and opioids with late compartment syndrome recognition (Safety_Signal + Follow-up stress)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: required increasing doses of opioids...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old male arrived at the emergency department at 11:00 PM after a sports-related injury causing a left supracondylar humerus fracture. Initial neurovascular assessment indicated a pink, warm hand, but the patient reported escalating pain levels over the next few hours, requiring increasing doses of opioids. Despite this, the orthopedic team delayed the surgical intervention until 04:00 AM due to staffing issues. At this time, the patient displayed late signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain on passive stretch. Immediate fasciotomy was performed, and the case highlights the critical need for timely recognition of compartment syndrome in the context of escalating pain and opioid use.
signals: Despite this, the orthopedic team delayed the surgical intervention until 04:00 AM due to staffing issues.
At this time, the patient displayed late signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain on passive stretch.

raw_results.scenario_label: Delay > 18h due to true lack of NPO status (ate breakfast) (Delay_Driver_Profiler)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: presented to the emergency department at 09:15 AM...

engine_output.raw_input: An 8-year-old male presented to the emergency department at 09:15 AM after sustaining a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture during a fall from a swing. The patient's mother reported that he had eaten breakfast at 07:30 AM. Initial neurovascular assessment revealed a pink, pulseless hand, and a negative AIN motor exam. Due to the recent intake of food, the patient was not cleared for anesthesia until 02:30 PM. Surgery was eventually initiated at 11:00 PM, resulting in a total delay of 13 hours. The orthopedic team noted no signs of compartment syndrome during the pre-op evaluation, and the patient's pulse was not palpable at the wrist. Overall, the surgical intervention was performed successfully with no immediate complications noted post-operatively.

raw_results.scenario_label: Transfer patient from rural hospital with Gartland III, arrived with compartment syndrome signs (Exclusion_Hunter)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: transferred from a rural hospital at 03:00 PM...

engine_output.raw_input: A 10-year-old girl was transferred from a rural hospital to our facility at 03:00 PM after sustaining a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture. Upon arrival, she exhibited early signs of compartment syndrome, including severe pain and swelling in the forearm, with a documented pressure of 40 mmHg on compartment measurement. Her neurovascular status was compromised with a white, cold pulseless hand. The orthopedic team rapidly assessed the situation, but due to the significant delay in transfer, definitive surgical intervention was initiated at 10:30 PM. The case was complicated by the initial lack of proper assessment at the rural facility, resulting in a need for urgent fasciotomy.

raw_results.scenario_label: Simple Gartland II, prompt reduction within 4 hours, no complications (Process_Auditor)

engine_output.raw_input: A 6-year-old boy presented to our emergency department at 10:45 AM with a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture after a fall while playing. He was assessed promptly, and his neurovascular examination demonstrated a pink, warm hand with full sensation. The orthopedic team prioritized his case due to the nature of the injury, and surgery was scheduled immediately. He was taken to the operating room by 02:00 PM, achieving a total time to OR of just over 3 hours. Post-operatively, he showed no signs of complications, and the AIN motor exam was intact.

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: surgery was delayed due to an overcrowded operating room, finally taken to the OR at 03:30 AM...

engine_output.raw_input: An 11-year-old female presented to the emergency department at 08:30 AM with a Gartland III supracondylar humerus fracture sustained during a soccer game. Initial examination revealed a pink hand with some sensory deficits, prompting urgent orthopedic consultation. However, due to an overcrowded operating room and multiple emergent cases, her surgery was delayed. The patient remained in the hospital for monitoring until 03:30 AM the next day when she was finally taken to the OR, resulting in a total delay of 19 hours. Throughout her stay, she was monitored for signs of compartment syndrome, which were not evident.

raw_results.scenario_label: Poly-trauma patient, SCH fixation delayed for neurosurgery clearance (Exclusion_Hunter)

errors: signals:Missing must_find_signals: brought to the emergency department at 07:45 PM, definitive fixation was delayed due to neurosurgical evaluation...

engine_output.raw_input: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department at 07:45 PM after being involved in a multi-vehicle accident. He sustained a Gartland II supracondylar humerus fracture along with a head injury. Due to the need for neurosurgical evaluation, his definitive fixation was delayed. Neurovascular assessment indicated a pink hand with full pulses but the orthopedic team was unable to proceed with surgery until 01:00 AM the next day after clearance from neurosurgery. Overall, the delay lasted 5 hours before he could undergo surgery, but the orthopedic team noted that this delay was justified given the patient's head injury.
